RIF-HEADER.AUTHOR: od@enso-managers.com
RIF-HEADER.COMMENT: System Specification of Project 'ReqIF-Server (Excerpt)'. It contains: * plans, * model elements, * requirements, * occurrences of model elements on plans, * relations between requirements and model elements, * dependencies between requirements, as well as * containment of model-elements.
RIF-HEADER.TITLE: ReqIF-Server (Excerpt)-20

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-STRING.DESC: This is a standard sting type
This is a standard text type

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-BOOLEAN.DESC: This is a standard boolean type

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-INTEGER.DESC: This is a standard signed integer type
This is a standard short integer type, also called NONNEGATIVE INTEGER

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-REAL.DESC: This is a standard real type
This is a standard real type with two digits

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-DATE.DESC: This is a standard date-time type in ISO Format

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-STRING.DESC: This is a standard e-mail address

DATATYPE-DEFINITION-ENUMERATION.DESC: Enumerated Values for the requirement status
Enumerated Values for the requirement priority
Enumerated Values for the reviewer status

SPEC-TYPE.DESC: A plan showing a usage scenario (business process) or the system topology.
A singular documented need of what a particular product or service should be or perform.
A system function (also process step), information container or event.
A reference from a requirement to another one it depends on (top->down).
A model element realizes a requirement.
A model-element is shown on a plan.
This is the root node of a hierarchy (tree) of Plans.
This is the root node of a hierarchy (tree) of Requirements.
This is the root node of a hierarchy (tree) of Model-Elements.
The actual title text is contained in objects of this type, rather than in the hierarchy node

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: External review of specifications using a web-application

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: External review of specifications using a web-application

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:div:
Many OEMs in the Automobile Industry use the IBM Rational DOORS for Requirement Management.
When cooperating with a supplier, the OEM provides a relevant subset of requirements, while the supplier adds comments and sets status values. The commented and modified data is returned to the OEM. This round-trip usually happens several times in the course of a project.
For native data exchange, however, the supplier organization needs to procure a DOORS software in order to work with the data. Especially in case of smaller suppliers or few projects, this investment is prohibitive.
This diagram shows another approach. A certain subset of requirements is exported in RIF-compliant files. The ReqIF-Server has a built-in generic browser to publish the content of the RIF-file in a set of web-pages. The supplier can update selected attributes and add comments using a web-browser of his choice.

Challenge: You would like to reference any information element contained in various modelling tools using web-links. For example, when specifying a software-solution you would like to reference the business process models it is supposed to support. Or, in a develop­ment task description you want to point to pertinent requirements. Or, in a bug ticket you would like to link the test-case having shown the bug.
Solution: Export the results of your modelling and specifi­ca­tion efforts to the Information Desk. Several methods exist, but most easy to use is the stan­dar­dized RIF/ReqIF (Requirement Interchange Format). The RIF/ReqIF meta model accepts virtually any speci­fication data, not just require­ments. The ReqIF Web-Services provide a permanent link ("Permalink", "URI") for each specification object.

Der ReqIF Server wird mit modellgetriebenen Methoden (MDD/MDT) entwickelt. - Systematische Struktur und gleichartiges Verhalten der Objekte - Die stufenweise Abstraktion erlaubt Flexibilität an der richtigen Stelle bei ordentlicher Performanz - Modellgetriebene Code-Generierung sichert hohes Qualitätsniveau
In principle, this process is similar for all roles, where only the functions are shown and made available for which the respective role has privileges.

Updating or deleting a requirement is about the same; instead of "create requirement" (an empty edit form opens) the function "edit requirement" (an edit form with actual property values opens) or the function "delete requirement" is selected.
How to navigate from dialog to dialog with the performed system operations.

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: So called "Demilitarized Zone" as the outer shell of an organization's IT security concept. All IT services accessible from externally are usually placed in the "DMZ".

All transactions are logged for auditing purposes with user and timestamp.
.. or: Transaction Log, Project Journal, Activity Log, Revision History, Audit Trail
Stores and retrieves User-Data to/from persistent storage.

"IBM Rational DOORS® software is a leading requirements management application that can help you reduce costs, increase efficiency and improve quality by enabling you to optimize requirements communication, collaboration and verification — throughout your organization and across your supply chain." (Source: http://www-01.ibm.com/software/awdtools/doors/)

Query and List SpecObjects. Selections are possible by SpecType, SpecGroup or SpecHierarchy.
Tbd: server-side filtering and page-wise loading.
The list of hierarchies, groups and types is included.
Query and List Projects and show the roles I have as a user.
- In a web-environment, the interactive client is ideally a portal plus a number of portlets. - In a native environment, the interactive client could be an Eclipse application.
Query and List Projects and show the roles I have as a user.
Query and List SpecObjects of a certain SpecType, such as Requirements.
Original Equipment Manufacturer, in this context it is the customer.

Permissions - Per item type, global create and delete permissions are granted. - Per item attribute, it is a vector with Read/Update permissions, including custom attributes. - Finally, a permission is needed to attach a comment to an item type or to establish a relationship between items.
Scope of permissions - Permissions may be given to all projects, in case of an administrator. - Typically, permissions apply to a specific project, - may be restricted to a pool (then, permissions on project level are overridden), or - may be even restricted to a set (then, permissions on project or pool level are overridden).
In future, - Permissions may even be granted to allow a transition from one life-cycle state to another. - Permissions may depend on the fact, whether an item was created by one-self or by anybody else.

The server interface of this function shall provide information reflecting the permissions of the client (caller). Thus, this layer passes the data which its client has a privilege to use and suppresses the data which the client has no privilege to use.
The structure of the data provided at its interface to the client (top) is exactly the same as the data received from its interface to the server (bottom).

The ReqIF Server is designed to process data according to the RIF and ReqIF standards as published by ProSTEP iViP and OMG respectively. RIF/ReqIF input data is interpreted with respect to informational structure and content so as to provide transactions in a multi-user and integrated application environment without further preparation. Information items are made available both via an interactive browser and via self-describing web-services according to the REST architecture model. ReqIF Views is intended for interactive access, whereas the web-services offer create, read, update and delete transactions for application integration. The informational structure, for example the hierarchies and groups of information items or rela­tions between items, is reflected in the interfaces to allow for easy navigation.
Since the RIF/ReqIF meta-model is much more versatile than for requirements and system specifications alone, the ReqIF Server can host a wide range of applications, such as transactional Informa­tion Desks or Directories. (Source: http://www.reqif.de/index.php/datasheet.html)

A module within a RM-Tool to export/import data to/from a ReqIF/RIF-compliant file.
The module is invoked through entries in the menue structure of the RM-Tool.

The entities of the RIF Meta-Model are abstract; i.e. they never appear in the Database, on the GUI, or in an exchange file. The meta-model is used for better structuring of the domain-model. Information elements appearing in the real system are instantiated from concrete (non-abstract) entities of the domain-model.
Relations between abstract entities translate to all derived concrete information elements.

The RIF/ReqIF file contains both the RIF model of a specification project and its data. So the types used can vary from project to project: - one project may just have requirements, - another project may consist of requirements, functions, information and events.

The RIF/ReqIF file contains both the RIF model of a specification project and its data. So the types used can vary from project to project: - one project may just have requirements, - another project may consist of requirements, functions, information and events.

A user role is valid in the context of a single project. It represents a group of privileges.
Roles are typical representations of users combining a number of permissions. Roles can be created and permissions can be freely associated to roles. Thus, a role represents a set of permissions. Roles can be associated to other roles in a hierarchical tree, in which the leaves are permissions.
The persistent storage of users and their association to role(s) is implemented such that it is easy to use a commonly used directory (LDAP or MS ActiveDirectory) for this purpose.

Views is a built-in generic user interface for display with a standard Web-Browser. - first the project attributes (RIF header), the SpecHierarchyRoots and the SpecTypes are shown, - Tables of SpecObjects with Attributes per SpecHierarchyRoot and - Lists of SpecObjects per SpecType are available, as well as - Detail views of every SpecType and SpecObject.
The detail views of SpecObjects encompass the standard and user-defined attributes, as well as the defined SpecRelations. Using links in the list of relations, it is possible to navigate from one SpecObject to related SpecObjects.
A ReqIF file is selected from the user's file system and uploaded to the ReqIF server using the Web-Browser. A project is created with the structure and content of the ReqIF file.
"Google layout": All SpecObjects are listed with a teaser (contents of selected attributes). Clicking an object shows a detail view of the object.
The attributes of the project (=ReqIF-Header) are displayed.

Show a SpecObject in a form with its details: - attributes - relationships - hierarchies
To be discussed: - show in a tab, a popup or in a separate frame.
All Projects are listed in a table with their attributes.
All SpecTypes are listed with their attributes.

In case an "embedded file" (i.e. stored in the ReqIF database) is an image which can be displayed by the web-browser, it is displayed within the space available. If larger than the available space, it is scaled down. If it is smaller, the original size is used (not scaled-up).
Option: a thumbnail is displayed. Clicking the thumbnail displays the image in a light-box.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: List SpecObjects in a tree by SpecHierarchy

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: List SpecObjects in a tree by SpecHierarchy

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE:
Browse the tree which is defined by one or more SpecHierarchyRoot with its children. An item can be associated to none, one or multiple nodes in the hierarchies.
If the view has a detail frame, the highlighted (selected) SpecObject is shown with all attributes. Otherwise a new tab with object details is opened upon click.
SpecObjects are shown as lines and their attributes as columns in a table. - As a user I can select visible columns by checkboxes in a context menue of the table header (or similar).

When viewing an embedded object (or embedded/referenced file), the client application is opened which is associated with the file extension (e.g. an OLE object with RTF-frame ist opened in MS Office Word). The standard web-browser and operating system features are used.
Navigation is simple and direct: - Detail views have Next/Previous buttons - Relations between SpecObjects can be followed

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: List SpecObjects in a table ("intelligent DOORS view")

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: List SpecObjects in a table ("intelligent DOORS view")

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: If it is recognized that the data has been exported from DOORS, it is arranged in a table such that it is presented similarly to DOORS.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Pagewise viewing of lists and tables

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Pagewise viewing of lists and tables

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: Long lists and tables are delivered pagewise. - Buttons "Previous" and "Next" page must be shown - Buttons with page numbers for direct navigation may be shown.
A project can be seleced (e.g. from a drop-down list) for further interaction.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Import and Export is RIF 1.2 compliant

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Import and Export is RIF 1.2 compliant

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE:
The import and export of XML-formatted data conforms to the Requirements Interchange Format (RIF), PSI 6, Version 1.2.
For details, please refer to: http://www.prostep.org/fileadmin/freie_downloads/Empfehlungen-Standards/ProSTEP_iViP/PSI_RIF_6_1.2.pdf

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Complex Data Type: XHTML text with embedded objects

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Complex Data Type: XHTML text with embedded objects

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: .. with XHTML formatting tags and embedded binary objects.

The meta model conforms to the Requirements Interchange Format (RIF), PSI 6, Version 1.2.
For details, please refer to: http://www.prostep.org/fileadmin/freie_downloads/Empfehlungen-Standards/ProSTEP_iViP/PSI_RIF_6_1.2.pdf

Any creation, update or deletion of data gets a consecutive 'over-all' revision number.
Conventions: - When updating, the next revision is assigned. - When reading with no revision specified, the most recent revision is returned, unless marked deleted. - When reading, 'revision > 0' means the specific revision ("absolute revision number"). - As revision numbers are unique within a project, a specific item has non-consecutive revision numbers. If a nonexistent revision number is requested, the next lower revision is returned. - When reading, 'revision = 0' means the most recent revision. - When reading, 'revision < 0' means the respective revision before the most recent, i.e. 'revision = -1' means second but last ("relative revision number") - Upon deletion, a new revision with deleted=true is created.
Question: all updates of a single transaction carry the same revision number? Better "transaction number"?

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Import and Export is RIF 1.1a compliant

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Import and Export is RIF 1.1a compliant

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: The import and export of XML-formatted data conforms to the Requirements Interchange Format (RIF) Version 1.1a.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Import and Export is RIF 1.0a compliant

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Import and Export is RIF 1.0a compliant

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: The import and export of XML-formatted data conforms to the Requirements Interchange Format (RIF) Version 1.0a.
For binary data, the format name, the MIME type, the file name suffix and the associated application type has to be specified.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Size of import file is up to 4GB (unzipped)

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Size of import file is up to 4GB (unzipped)

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: Example file has 37 specObjects with 7 embedded OLE-Objects. XML: 100kB, OLE-Objects 11 MB, packed as ZIP: 630 kB
A RIF/ReqIF file is imported. If a project with equal ID exists, it will be replaced, otherwise created.
... where inside is one of the supported RIF/ReqIF file formats plus other referenced files in subdirectories.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Import of 4GB import file takes less than x hours

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Import of 4GB import file takes less than x hours

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: Text export is loss-less. In particular, all special characters, fonts and codepages are correctly transformed into an internationally viable, web-compatible format according to the RIF/ReqIF standard.

Binary Objects (embedded and referenced files) are modified/transformed such that they can be viewed with a web-browser and/or processed in an automatic document generation process. For example, acceptable formats are SVG/PNG images and PDF documents.
This may not always be possible, for example with large excel sheets. In this case a warning or error message is issued.

For easy reference all embedded files have an alias corresponding to their original file name. Knowing the file name and path of the original file shall be sufficient to address the file via ReqIF Server.
Example: If a file is delivered in a ZIP-container in the subdirectory "/images/filename.png", a URI is made available: "https://www.exxcellent.de/rif-server/v0.31/projects/{project-id}/content/images/filename.png".
(Whether "content" or "additional-content" as used today is an adequate qualifier in the path, should be discusssed. Perhaps "resources", "files" or "referenced-files" is better.)

The active user is the one who has logged into the application server (Tomcat). There are two built-in roles: - Reviewer: he has the privileges within a project as spevified in the RIF/ReqIF file. - ReqIF Admin: "root" privileges within the ReqIF Server for all projects.

- There are no revisions of DataTypes and SpecTypes. - SpecHierarchies versionable or not - tbd. - SpecObjects, SpecRelations and SpecGroups are versionable. - SpecObjects are stored in revisions as a whole - i.e. every SpecObject revision has their own attribute values. - How to deal with relations? - tbd.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Product is installed on general purpose OS

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Product is installed on general purpose OS

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: Least secure: the product is installed among others on the operating system. Only built-in security mechanisms are used. E.g., data is stored in the users private home directory and data access protection provided by the operating system is applied.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Web-Browser MS Internet Explorer is supported

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Web-Browser MS Internet Explorer is supported

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Product is released for MS Windows Server

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Product is released for MS Windows Server

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE: The application can be used remotely with a standard web-browser. Popular plugins such as Adobe PDF Reader and Adobe Flash Player can be assumed to be installed.

SPEC-OBJECT.LONG-NAME: Web-Services conform to REST/XML architecture model

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:strong: Web-Services conform to REST/XML architecture model

ATTRIBUTE-VALUE-SIMPLE.THE-VALUE:
Any object can be accessed via URI and HTTP-methods POST, GET, PUT, DELETE. The parameters are exchanged in (self-describing) XML-Format.
There are some definitive advantages to REST when compared to SOAP, especially in operation and security. For example, have a look at: http://www.oio.de/public/xml/rest-webservices.htm

.. as proposed by ProSTEP iViP (Use Case UC-6):
CHARACTERISTIC INFORMATION Goal in Context: Customer (OEM) sends Specification to one or more Reviewers (Suppliers). Reviewers send commented Specification back to Customer. The comments of the various Reviewers have to be visible in the RM-Tool, so that the Specification can be consolidated accordingly to the Review comments. Scope: The exchange of the Requirements Data. Level: Summary. Preconditions: Customer and Reviewer have a RM-Tool installed (or at least are able to emulate the functionality of state-of-the-art RM-Tools). Success End Condition: The comments of the various reviewers are visible in the customers RM-Tool database close to the commented area of the Specification. Failed End Condition: t.b.d. Primary Actor: Customer. Trigger: Customer sends out Specification for Review.
MAIN SUCCESS SCENARIO Step 1: Customer sends Specification to one or more Reviewers. Step 2: Reviewers comment Specification (set status, comment, question). Step 3: Reviewers send back commented Specification. Step 4: Import of the comments of the various Reviewers into Customers RM-Tool. Step 5: Comments of the various Reviewers are visible in the customers RM-Tool database close to the commented area of the Specification, so that the Specification can be consolidated according to comments.
Source: http://www.prostep.org/fileadmin/freie_downloads/Empfehlungen-Standards/ProSTEP_iViP/PSI_RIF_6_1.2.pdf

.. as proposed by ProSTEP iViP (Use Case UC-8):
CHARACTERISTIC INFORMATION Goal in Context: Customer (OEM) wants an editable or printable document that contains requirements from a RIF file. Scope: The exchange of the Requirements Data. Preconditions: Customer has a RIF file from which he wants to generate documentation from. Success End Condition: A document in a different format is generated. Failed End Condition: Primary Actor: Customer. Trigger: Customer needs an editable or printable version of the requirements.
MAIN SUCCESS SCENARIO Step 1: Customer creates a document from requirements contained in a RIF file.
Source: http://www.prostep.org/fileadmin/freie_downloads/Empfehlungen-Standards/ProSTEP_iViP/PSI_RIF_6_1.2.pdf

Comparative Request for Proposal: - Each supplier gets access to a project of his own with equal contents. - A supplier can comment in selected attribute fields per requirement. - A supplier cannot see the answers of the competitors (privileges are confined to his own project). - Per supplier, the updated information will be returned to the OEM.

XHTML-CONTENT.rif-xhtml:div:
The use cases are implemented by one or more of the Clients. They are included into the server spec only to give a general overview on how the total system will be used.
They are not part of the system to be implemented in the context of the RIF-Server.
Real World Scenarios are collected, here.
Requirements related to system response time, processing speed and data capacity.
Implementation options result in design decisions.
